verb.description: Bring down (one's foot) heavily on the ground or on something on the ground.
examples: he stamped his foot in frustration
he threw his cigarette down and stamped on it
Robertson stamped on all these suggestions

verb.description: Impress a pattern or mark, especially an official one, on (a surface, object, or document) using an engraved or inked block or die or other instrument.
Affix a postage stamp or stamps onto (a letter or package)
examples: Annie stamped the envelope for her

noun.description: An instrument for stamping a pattern or mark, in particular an engraved or inked block or die.
A small adhesive piece of paper stuck to something to show that an amount of money has been paid, in particular a postage stamp.
An act or sound of stamping with the foot.
examples: the stamp of boots on the bare floor

noun.description: A block for crushing ore in a stamp mill.

phrases: he must be able to stamp his authority on the team
In the second round, Pickering began to stamp his authority on the contest.
The prime minister, has moved swiftly to attempt to stamp his authority on Somalia's 10 million citizens.
Despite a move to his favoured central position the England captain failed to stamp his authority on the game.
Passes were sent astray on a continuous basis with the result neither side could stamp their authority on proceedings.
he stamped out the flames before they could grow
urgent action is required to stamp out corruption
Dr Barry wants increased police patrols in the village to help stamp the problem out.
The Romans did not succeed in stamping out any aspect of Egyptian religious magic.
New by-laws are set to be introduced in the town to stamp out anti-social behaviour.
origin: Middle English (in the sense crush to a powder): of Germanic origin; related to German stampfen stamp with the foot; reinforced by Old French estamper to stamp. Compare with stomp.
